snippet.textDisplay: Being Autistic myself, I find some of their traits or experience relatable (or familiar with from other Autistic people I know). There's not a lot of people who understands people with autism, not giving them the right support they need but it's good for you to get to know them and I hope more people would be willing to get to know them better too like this, for more people to be educated about autism.

I have low functioning autism myself and besides that I'd say I'm quite sensitive not as in emotional though however I do feel like people with autism myself included can be very empathetic while others with autism do struggle with that so it really depends.
In general I think other people with different qualities such as autism are amazing and inspiring people and the ones in the video also seemed very kind! <3

It's good to hear from the perspective of these people it helps me to better understand and I'm glad they have this opportunity to discuss it openly with no judgement.

snippet.textDisplay: To anyone who would like to understand more about how people from the spectrum  perceive the world, I really recommend Netflix series called "Atypical". I do not have any autistic relatives nor friends, however I feel that it may serve a good purpose in the future. The series are lovely, light and insanely humorous. Incredible material, Anthony. You did a fantastic job.
snippet.textOriginal: To anyone who would like to understand more about how people from the spectrum  perceive the world, I really recommend Netflix series called "Atypical". You did a fantastic job.

snippet.textDisplay:
Great vídeo! Im autistic and also have ADHD, so a lot of the stuff was relatable. But when i grew up i didnt see it affecting me as much as now (the same with ADHD), but i was a pretty lonely kid (i wasn't sad because of it, i just didn't feel like interacting that much with people), was almost always reading or drawing, they were my spins (and drawing still is) and i had (and still have) a lot of problems with eating a lot of stuff because of sensory issues. I am not diagnosed to either of those, but i don't mind it, i actually have a bit of a visceral reaction when people suggest me to get an official diagnosis, idk it just feels very intrusive

And one thing to say, functioning labels aren't the best, since they can be very ableist to make someone labeled high functioning unable to get help and someone labeled low functioning can be prohibited of being independent. And just because someone does better in social activities doesn't mean that they are "less autistic" or something like this
snippet.textOriginal:
Great vídeo! Im autistic and also have ADHD, so a lot of the stuff was relatable. But when i grew up i didnt see it affecting me as much as now (the same with ADHD), but i was a pretty lonely kid (i wasn't sad because of it, i just didn't feel like interacting that much with people), was almost always reading or drawing, they were my spins (and drawing still is) and i had (and still have) a lot of problems with eating a lot of stuff because of sensory issues. I am not diagnosed to either of those, but i don't mind it, i actually have a bit of a visceral reaction when people suggest me to get an official diagnosis, idk it just feels very intrusive

And one thing to say, functioning labels aren't the best, since they can be very ableist to make someone labeled high functioning unable to get help and someone labeled low functioning can be prohibited of being independent. And just because someone does better in social activities doesn't mean that they are "less autistic" or something like this

snippet.textDisplay: I have autism and I was diagnosed when I was around 11 years old. Since I was diagnosed at that age when I was in elementary school I was known as the slow kid because I couldn’t tie shoes or because I didn’t know my left from right but I was also known as the weird kid because I didn’t know how to socialize and I would play by myself. Also it was worse with my family because they didn’t/ don’t know I have autism and my family is Hispanic so they love to pick on you and so I would pick on because I didn’t know how to do certain chores or because I would say things without thinking about it or I couldn’t communicate well, but now that I’m older I understand a little bit more than when I was a kid so I’m able to socialize in a way I don’t seem ‘strange ‘ to others and I’m almost ‘normal’
snippet.textOriginal: I have autism and I was diagnosed when I was around 11 years old. Since I was diagnosed at that age when I was in elementary school I was known as the slow kid because I couldn’t tie shoes or because I didn’t know my left from right but I was also known as the weird kid because I didn’t know how to socialize and I would play by myself. Also it was worse with my family because they didn’t/ don’t know I have autism and my family is Hispanic so they love to pick on you and so I would pick on because I didn’t know how to do certain chores or because I would say things without thinking about it or I couldn’t communicate well, but now that I’m older I understand a little bit more than when I was a kid so I’m able to socialize in a way I don’t seem ‘strange ‘ to others and I’m almost ‘normal’

snippet.textDisplay:
I wish more people were educated about mental health in general. For instance, autism and ADHD are developmental disorders, meaning, the person had these more than likely since birth. Their brain thinks and is constructed differently. For some people, autism is pretty neutral in affecting their lives. For others, it can be a living nightmare.


The only positive for me from it is that I see a lot of social constructs like the way we communicate to be just convoluted and dumb. If your friend doesn't look great in that dress, you aren't helping them by lying. If I'm acting like a dickweed, I want people to tell me, even if it temporarily hurts my feelings. We can only become better people by having others call us out on our crap, because we can not see our own biases.

For me, I personally would rather not be autistic. Any positives I get from it are far outweighed by the emotional insecurity and inability to handle small problems. If I get upset, even over something small, I might cry or even panic. I feel out of control of myself and how I want to see myself. I feel weak and helpless to respond to things in an adult way. I also have trouble with sensory input, so certain foods, colors, textures can genuinely upset me and I've had to forgoe a meal because a texture made me feel ill. And I'm aware of all of it. I get cognitive dissonance because I experience two versions of the same story. My logical side gets that say I spilled water and that sucks, but it's okay, I just clean it up. But my emotional side flips out, starts bullying me, starts panicking and wishing to reverse time. It's jarring to feel two entirely different responses and to also know that the emotional upset will absolutely win. It creates an unhealthy view of emotions when they are volatile, especially over things you know aren't a big deal.
It's like watching myself get into a train wreck and there isn't a damn thing I can do about it.

I don't know how self-aware a lot of people are to their disorders, but I can only imagine what a lower functioning autistic experience must be like. Because I am not happy about being autistic personally and I just barely make the scale for a diagnosis.


Also, you're a terrible person if you don't vaccinate. Not just stupid, but a horrible human being. Many people have died because of the stigma to autism by not vaccinating their kids or themselves, but somehow they think death is better and I'm mortified by that train of thought. "Screw science and logic, I want to feel important and like I know things about the world, so I'm gonna buck against the system, even if it kills me or others, preferably others." Like, no, you are a terrible human being and a special snowflake and you're one of the few types of people in the world I have little sympathy or tolerance for. I will not entertain or be cordial to people who believe nonsense that actually harms other people.
snippet.textOriginal:

Their brain thinks and is constructed differently. For some people, autism is pretty neutral in affecting their lives. For others, it can be a living nightmare.


The only positive for me from it is that I see a lot of social constructs like the way we communicate to be just convoluted and dumb. If your friend doesn't look great in that dress, you aren't helping them by lying. If I'm acting like a dickweed, I want people to tell me, even if it temporarily hurts my feelings. We can only become better people by having others call us out on our crap, because we can not see our own biases.

For me, I personally would rather not be autistic. Any positives I get from it are far outweighed by the emotional insecurity and inability to handle small problems. If I get upset, even over something small, I might cry or even panic. I feel out of control of myself and how I want to see myself. I feel weak and helpless to respond to things in an adult way. I also have trouble with sensory input, so certain foods, colors, textures can genuinely upset me and I've had to forgoe a meal because a texture made me feel ill. And I'm aware of all of it. It's jarring to feel two entirely different responses and to also know that the emotional upset will absolutely win. It creates an unhealthy view of emotions when they are volatile, especially over things you know aren't a big deal. 
It's like watching myself get into a train wreck and there isn't a damn thing I can do about it.

I don't know how self-aware a lot of people are to their disorders, but I can only imagine what a lower functioning autistic experience must be like. Because I am not happy about being autistic personally and I just barely make the scale for a diagnosis.


Also, you're a terrible person if you don't vaccinate. Not just stupid, but a horrible human being. Like, no, you are a terrible human being and a special snowflake and you're one of the few types of people in the world I have little sympathy or tolerance for. I will not entertain or be cordial to people who believe nonsense that actually harms other people.

snippet.textDisplay: I was constantly bullied in school as well and I’m totally normal. Kids, and burnt out teachers, can be real assholes. Aside from the trauma I still work through it’s given me a unique and incredibly skeptical outlook on life and people which does help me out in many situations. And though I’m extraverted, I have a real appreciation spending time by myself and with people I really trust :). I also have an appreciation for anyone who comes across differently and I find it refreshing and it makes me curious to learn more about them! Such a cool video, and I would totally be friends with any of these people, they all seem really bright and sweet!
snippet.textOriginal: I was constantly bullied in school as well and I’m totally normal. Kids, and burnt out teachers, can be real assholes. Aside from the trauma I still work through it’s given me a unique and incredibly skeptical outlook on life and people which does help me out in many situations. And though I’m extraverted, I have a real appreciation spending time by myself and with people I really trust :). I also have an appreciation for anyone who comes across differently and I find it refreshing and it makes me curious to learn more about them! Such a cool video, and I would totally be friends with any of these people, they all seem really bright and sweet!

snippet.textDisplay: I’m a teacher aide, who has worked with students with autism in the past. One student in particular is why I aspire to be a head of learning support one day and why I decided to settle on being a teacher aide. He changed my life. It’s so refreshing to see others with the same empowering and inspiring mindset about autism. At the end of the day we are all people. One thing about the video that stood out to me in particular was the discussion of “person with autism” versus “autistic person” ... I have always been told by teachers, supervisors, etc, to say “person with autism” rather than “autistic person”. Now I know it is a matter of personal preference I will definitely be more aware of that. It really is true when they say if you’ve met a person who has autism, you’ve met one person who has autism. :-) Thank you for covering a topic close to my heart with such tact and depth. It really broke my heart to hear about that teacher. Some people should not be working in the education industry ... simple as that.
snippet.textOriginal: I’m a teacher aide, who has worked with students with autism in the past. One thing about the video that stood out to me in particular was the discussion of “person with autism” versus “autistic person” ... I have always been told by teachers, supervisors, etc, to say “person with autism” rather than “autistic person”. Now I know it is a matter of personal preference I will definitely be more aware of that. It really is true when they say if you’ve met a person who has autism, you’ve met one person who has autism. :-) Thank you for covering a topic close to my heart with such tact and depth. It really broke my heart to hear about that teacher. Some people should not be working in the education industry ... simple as that.

snippet.textDisplay: When people who don't have exposure to people on the spectrum, I think it's common to come up with an idea of a cold, socially awkward, geeky, straight man. And not the normal diversity there is in the autism community, just like in anything else. Women, poc, lgbt,people with actual personalities. So I really love that you're using your platform to give this community a voice!
snippet.textOriginal: When people who don't have exposure to people on the spectrum, I think it's common to come up with an idea of a cold, socially awkward, geeky, straight man. So I really love that you're using your platform to give this community a voice!

snippet.textDisplay: Jasmine at the end saying that having autism and being on the spectrum isn't an excuse to misbehave just reminds me of my best friend. My best friend has Asperger's and she is constantly using it as an excuse for the way she used to treat me. She's getting better about it and she doesn't treat me badly anymore but she used to use it as the only reason why she would act so horribly with me. She uses to just say that she didn't understand what I was asking of her or that it was much more difficult for her to switch from one task to another because that's a part of her Asperger's syndrome, but I could easily tell that was a lie because I had seen her do it before and I could tell that she just didn't want to put in the effort to be my friend. She wanted all the benefits without working for it herself, which wasn't fair for me, so thankfully I talked with her and even had her mom intervene and now she is paying more attention to the way she treats me and how she acts
snippet.textOriginal: Jasmine at the end saying that having autism and being on the spectrum isn't an excuse to misbehave just reminds me of my best friend. My best friend has Asperger's and she is constantly using it as an excuse for the way she used to treat me. She's getting better about it and she doesn't treat me badly anymore but she used to use it as the only reason why she would act so horribly with me. She uses to just say that she didn't understand what I was asking of her or that it was much more difficult for her to switch from one task to another because that's a part of her Asperger's syndrome, but I could easily tell that was a lie because I had seen her do it before and I could tell that she just didn't want to put in the effort to be my friend. She wanted all the benefits without working for it herself, which wasn't fair for me, so thankfully I talked with her and even had her mom intervene and now she is paying more attention to the way she treats me and how she acts

snippet.textDisplay: As a person with Down Syndrome this hits me hard because people with abilities that I don’t say disabilities because it’s not a diss. We all as human beings are being mistreated and discriminated by nasty negative people that say we sensitive. It’s just that we are sensitive by your hurtful ways to attack of our character. We all are normal with an ingredient with this recipe that God gave us. That’s all it is. I’ve been beaten up and been harassed by teachers, students, friends so called, even Police themselves. I don’t want any sympathy I want someone to realize words can hurt like physical tension. It equals it out and I thank you Padilla for this. A real thank you! 🙏🏼

snippet.textDisplay:
Let's exploit this video to find some friends.

Book1
Do you consider Don Tilman (protagonist) from The Rosie Project (written by Graeme Simsion) as autistic?

My definition of autism = I can relate to the way they think, while characters in the book call him out for it.
(Characters: That's unusual; Me: No it's not, I'd do the same.)

Example: He tried to find a marriage partner by making a survey with single women. (Not because he's narcisstic but because it's the woman he would marry, hello?!) What a great guy.

Book2
What is your opinion to House Rules? (written by Jodi Picoult) The son of the protagonist is already estabilished as having Asperger. Do you think the depiction of him was relatable? The main view was from the mother who had to raise him. The rest consisted of info dumps about forensic.

I hope some people read this... or have at least read these books or even read books in the first place. (Looking for book friends on YouTube, I must be insane!)
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: One of my criticisms with this video is they’re only interviewing autistic people who appear to be in their 20’s. Autistic people who are in their 20’s, had a very different journey than those of use who aren’t in our 20’s, and in a more varied age group with autism. It wouldn’t take a lot of work for them to find autistic people in a more of a varied age group to get a better perspective. Seriously if those running this channel want help, with a more diverse group, I’m in Los Angeles County, and they’re welcome to contact me. I have friends of different age ranges, and racial backgrounds who are also on the autism spectrum, who could give a more diverse, and realistic perspective on this subject.
snippet.textOriginal: One of my criticisms with this video is they’re only interviewing autistic people who appear to be in their 20’s. Autistic people who are in their 20’s, had a very different journey than those of use who aren’t in our 20’s, and in a more varied age group with autism. It wouldn’t take a lot of work for them to find autistic people in a more of a varied age group to get a better perspective. Seriously if those running this channel want help, with a more diverse group, I’m in Los Angeles County, and they’re welcome to contact me. I have friends of different age ranges, and racial backgrounds who are also on the autism spectrum, who could give a more diverse, and realistic perspective on this subject.

snippet.textDisplay: As someone that has a brother with severe autism, this is awesome to see. Not enough people understand or are willing to understand autism. My only concern is that videos like this or reports or whatever that spend time with high functioning autistic people are double edged swords. While one end of the spectrum is shown, the severe end (the side my brother is on) is largely not discussed. Anthony did much more than I’ve ever even seen before by simply mentioning the severe end. That said, however, I don’t think it’s shown enough. All of these people are able to talk. They’re able to form complete and complex sentences. They can drive. They can sit in a chair and have a conversation. Etc. My brother can’t do any of these things. He speaks in fragments of sentences. He can’t drive let alone sit at the diner table and use a fork properly. I was in special family groups and programs when I was a kid where I got to meet other families and autistic children. I’d say about 50% were probably low functioning so it’s certainly not uncommon. I’m not trying to say that the abilities of these people in the video are insignificant at all, though. I applaud all of the guests for this video for being able to sit their and talk about their lives and experiences to Anthony. I think it’s absolutely incredible and is hard for a typical person to do let alone an autistic person. I can’t imagine how hard it was physically and mentally for them to sit there and be engaged in conversation. All I want to do is recommend that those people who are inspired by this video go out and find examples of people with severe autism too. Listen to their families’ struggles and victories. It’s just the next step in normalizing autism.
snippet.textOriginal: As someone that has a brother with severe autism, this is awesome to see. Not enough people understand or are willing to understand autism. My only concern is that videos like this or reports or whatever that spend time with high functioning autistic people are double edged swords. While one end of the spectrum is shown, the severe end (the side my brother is on) is largely not discussed. Anthony did much more than I’ve ever even seen before by simply mentioning the severe end. That said, however, I don’t think it’s shown enough. All of these people are able to talk. They’re able to form complete and complex sentences. They can drive. They can sit in a chair and have a conversation. Etc. My brother can’t do any of these things. He speaks in fragments of sentences. He can’t drive let alone sit at the diner table and use a fork properly. I was in special family groups and programs when I was a kid where I got to meet other families and autistic children. I’d say about 50% were probably low functioning so it’s certainly not uncommon. I’m not trying to say that the abilities of these people in the video are insignificant at all, though. I applaud all of the guests for this video for being able to sit their and talk about their lives and experiences to Anthony. I think it’s absolutely incredible and is hard for a typical person to do let alone an autistic person. I can’t imagine how hard it was physically and mentally for them to sit there and be engaged in conversation. All I want to do is recommend that those people who are inspired by this video go out and find examples of people with severe autism too. Listen to their families’ struggles and victories. It’s just the next step in normalizing autism.

snippet.textDisplay: As a teen with autism, thank you for this video. It helps me understand my disability a bit more, and to know about how others are with autism.. as I still don't quite understand what happens in my day-to-day life having this trait.

snippet.textDisplay: I know a girl with autism, she is the kindest sweetest person and she gets sooo interested in art and she sometimes draws funny little illustrations and everyone finds them hilarious, her and I even consider it an advantage. She sees the world as a happy place she is never sad.

snippet.textDisplay: i was kinda worried clicking on this video ngl because i wasn’t sure how it was all going to go down. i’m glad to see anthony treated them with a ton of respect and just like he would anyone else he interviews. my brother has autism and it’s hard for him to communicate things like what they discussed in this so i’m glad i learned a bit more about the disability so i can try my best to understand the things my brother experiences sometimes. anyway, great video dude 👍

snippet.textDisplay: please do someone with muscular dystrophy! there are so many types and not many people know about the different types and how there lives changed because of it. i would love to get to know more about my disease, CMT, which stands for charcot-marie-tooth.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't have autism but I do have ADD. I was diagnosed when I was 9 and when I was diagnosed it changed everything for me as it meant I could get the help I needed. Before I was diagnosed I almost failed out of school my first two years of grade school. I find it very important for people not to treat others different just because they are different. When I told people I had ADD teachers would treat me different than everybody else and it wasn't very great for me. I'm glad you want to learn more about disorders and that you don't treat them differently and that you are sharing what you learn with the world.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't have autism but I do have ADD. I was diagnosed when I was 9 and when I was diagnosed it changed everything for me as it meant I could get the help I needed. Before I was diagnosed I almost failed out of school my first two years of grade school. I find it very important for people not to treat others different just because they are different. When I told people I had ADD teachers would treat me different than everybody else and it wasn't very great for me. I'm glad you want to learn more about disorders and that you don't treat them differently and that you are sharing what you learn with the world.

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly a person centred approach is saying “people with/living with” said disability. They aren’t the disability, just people with different circumstances. Clinically yes, most would say “insert disability” person....but having worked with people livings with disabilities for some time, in a person centred environment, clinical isn’t the way to go.
snippet.textOriginal: Honestly a person centred approach is saying “people with/living with” said disability. They aren’t the disability, just people with different circumstances. Clinically yes, most would say “insert disability” person....but having worked with people livings with disabilities for some time, in a person centred environment, clinical isn’t the way to go.

snippet.textDisplay: As a proud mommy of a child with autism, thank you so much for this video. Thank you for sharing theirs truths, and treating, and talking to them the same as you would anyone else.

snippet.textDisplay: 7:18 This really needs to be said more. People always act like people with mental disorders are victims and they always felt bad for who they are but in reality... Every person I've talked to and myself have always said they didnt really know their mind was weird until they saw how normal people worked or their parents suspected the disorder
snippet.textOriginal: 7:18 This really needs to be said more. People always act like people with mental disorders are victims and they always felt bad for who they are but in reality... Every person I've talked to and myself have always said they didnt really know their mind was weird until they saw how normal people worked or their parents suspected the disorder
